glossary.name: A/A Test
glossary.definition: An A/B test in which the experiences being tested are identical to one another. This is done in an effort to determine statistical validity of the A/B tool, the metric being monitored, and the analysis process being used.

glossary.name: A/B Testing
glossary.definition: The process of providing two or more different experiences across two or more subgroups of a population. The goal is to measure the change in behavior of the subgroups upon receiving the respective experiences.

glossary.name: Accuracy
glossary.definition: The number of true positives plus the number of true negatives divided by the total number of examples.

glossary.name: Activation Function
glossary.definition: The function used on the output of a neuron. These activations can be linear or nonlinear. If they're nonlinear, they can be symmetric or asymmetric.

glossary.name: Adagrad
glossary.definition: An optimizer used to update the weights of a neural network in which different learning rates are applied to different weights.

glossary.name: Adam
glossary.definition: A common gradient descent optimizer that takes advantage of momentum and adaptive learning rates.

glossary.name: Agglomerative Clustering
glossary.definition: A clustering algorithm that builds a hierarchy of subclusters that gradually group into a single cluster. Some techniques for measuring distances between clusters are single-linkage and complete-linkage methods.

glossary.name: Amazon Kinesis
glossary.definition: An AWS product that provides a way to handle real-time data streaming.

glossary.name: Apache Airflow
glossary.definition: A workflow management system that provides users a way to author, schedule, and execute software.

glossary.name: Apache Kafka
glossary.definition: An open-source software platform which provides a way to handle real-time data streaming.

glossary.name: Apache Spark
glossary.definition: A software interface which provides implicit parallelism and fault tolerance across a cluster of machines.

glossary.name: Apache YARN
glossary.definition: A software product responsible for managing compute resources across a cluster of machines.

glossary.name: Arithmetic Mean
glossary.definition: The average of a series of numbers.

glossary.name: Automated Machine Learning (Auto-ML)
glossary.definition: A strategy which automates the process of applying features and labels to a machine learning model.

glossary.name: Availability Zone (AZ)
glossary.definition: Typically a single data center within a region which has two or more data centers. The term "multi-AZ" implies that an application or software resource is present across more than one AZ within a region. This strategy allows the software resource to continue operating even if a data center becomes unavailable.

glossary.name: Avro
glossary.definition: A row-oriented data serializer provided by Apache.

glossary.name: Backpropagation
glossary.definition: The use of the derivative chain rule along with dynamic programming to determine the gradients of the loss function in neural networks.

glossary.name: Backpropagation Through Time
glossary.definition: Backpropagation within an RNN in which an additional partial derivative term is calculated per time step that the input required.

glossary.name: Bagging
glossary.definition: Also bootstrap aggregation, a sampling technique which selects subsets of examples and/or features to train an ensemble of models. This generally reduces the variance error.

glossary.name: Batch Normalization
glossary.definition: The process of normalizing values by means of re-centering (subtracting the mean) or re-scaling (dividing by the standard deviation) before they go to subsequent layers in a neural network. The goal is to accelerate the learning of deep neural networks by decreasing the number of epochs required for the loss function to converge.

glossary.name: Bernoulli Distribution
glossary.definition: A distribution which evaluates a particular outcome as binary. In the Bernoulli Naive Bayes classifier case, a word was either in a message or not in a message, which is binary representation.

glossary.name: Beta Distribution
glossary.definition: This distribution is used to model percentages and proportions such as click-through probabilities.

glossary.name: Bias-variance Tradeoff
glossary.definition:
A pursuit of balance between the errors produced by the bias and the variance of a particular model. The higher the bias, or assumptions injected into the model, typically the more bias error is produced. This generally results in a model which underfits the training examples, which means the assumptions limit the model's ability to properly learn.

In contrast, the fewer assumptions are injected into the model, the more variance is allowed in the model parameters, which means the model may learn from the noise in the training examples. This generally results in a model which overfits the training examples, which means the lack of assumptions limit the model's ability to properly learn.

The errors from the bias and variance, combined with the irreducible error, make up the overall model error. Both overfitting and underfitting can inhibit the model's ability to generalize or predict the labels of the test examples.

glossary.name: Binary Classification
glossary.definition: A supervised learning task in which there are two possible outputs.

glossary.name: Bisected K-means
glossary.definition: Using k-means with k equal to 2 for subsets of the examples in an effort to reduce the chance of converging to a local optima.

glossary.name: Boosting
glossary.definition: An ensemble technique which trains many weak learners sequentially, with each subsequent weak learner being trained on the previous weak learner's error. This generally reduces the bias error.

glossary.name: Candidate Generator
glossary.definition: A system which outputs the candidates to be ranked. This is sometimes referred to as retrieving the â€˜top-k'

glossary.name: Cell State
glossary.definition: Used within a Long short-term memory (LSTM) acting as an additional hidden state.

glossary.name: Central Processing Unit (CPU)
glossary.definition: A general purpose compute resource responsible for executing computer programs.

glossary.name: Centroid
glossary.definition: The location of the center of a cluster in n-dimensions.

glossary.name: Change Data Capture
glossary.definition:
The process of recording changes in the data within a database system. For instance, if a user cancels their Netflix subscription, then the row in some table will change to indicate that they're no longer a subscriber.

The change in this row can be recorded and referenced later for analysis or audit purposes.

glossary.name: Channels
glossary.definition: The number of stacked images, typically representing Red Green Blue pixels, or the number of feature maps produced by a convolutional layer.

glossary.name: Classification and Regression Tree
glossary.definition: Also CART, is an algorithm for constructing an approximate optimal decision tree for given examples.

glossary.name: Clickstream
glossary.definition: An ordered series of interactions that users have with some interface. In the traditional sense, this can be literal clicks of a mouse on a desktop browser. Interactions can also come from touchscreens and conversational user interfaces.

glossary.name: Closed-Form Solution
glossary.definition: For our case, this is what ordinary least squares provides for linear regression. It's a formula which solves an equation.

glossary.name: Cluster
glossary.definition: A consolidated group of points.

glossary.name: Coefficient
glossary.definition: Another name for a parameter in the regression model.

glossary.name: Cold-start
glossary.definition: A challenge with recommendation systems in which users or items are new and that there is limited or no information in terms of the user-item matrix. This can make personalized recommendations difficult or impossible.

glossary.name: Collaborative Filtering
glossary.definition: A recommendation technique which uses many user's and item's data typically in the form of a user-item matrix.

glossary.name: Collinearity
glossary.definition: When one or more (multicollinearity) independent variables are not actually independent.

glossary.name: Concurrency
glossary.definition: When two or computer programs share a single processor.

glossary.name: Confidence Interval
glossary.definition: The possible range of an unknown value. Often comes with some degree of probability e.g. 95% confidence interval.

glossary.name: Confusion Matrix
glossary.definition: In the binary case, a 2x2 matrix indicating the number of true positives, true negatives, false positives and false negatives.

glossary.name: Constrained Optimization
glossary.definition: Opposed to an unconstrained optimization problem in which we can use gradient descent, optimization problems with constraints usually require other optimization methods. If there are equality constraints, Lagrange multipliers can often be used. If there are inequality constraints, then linear or quadratic programming can often be used.

glossary.name: Content Filtering
glossary.definition: A recommendation technique which takes into account a single user's features and many items' features.

glossary.name: Convex Function
glossary.definition: Function with one optima.

glossary.name: Convolutional Layer
glossary.definition: Similar to a fully connected neural layer; however, each neuron is only connected to a subset of neurons in the subsequent layer with respect to a receptive field.

glossary.name: Cookie
glossary.definition: A small piece of data stored by a browser which indicates stateful information for a particular website. For instance, a cookie can be stored in your browser after you log in to a website to indicate that you are logged in. This will stop subsequent pages from asking you to log in again.

glossary.name: Correlation
glossary.definition: The relationship between a dependent and independent variable.

glossary.name: Cosine Similarity
glossary.definition: A similarity metric which is equal to the cosine of the angle between two inputs in some embedding space.

glossary.name: Cross-Entropy Loss
glossary.definition: A loss function which is used in classification tasks. It's technically the entropy of the true labels plus the KL-divergence of the predicted and true labels. Minimizing the cross-entropy minimizes the difference between the true and predicted label distributions.

glossary.name: Data Governance
glossary.definition: The method of managing, using, and protecting an organization's data.

glossary.name: Data Ingestion
glossary.definition: A subsystem responsible for processing incoming data. Typically, the data comes from clickstreams, change data captures, or existing data stores.

glossary.name: Data Parallelism
glossary.definition: A machine learning model training strategy used to maximize the utilization of compute resources (CPUs/GPUs) in which the data is distributed across two or more devices

glossary.name: Data Processing
glossary.definition: The process of altering data by means of aggregation, joins, transformations, and others.

glossary.name: Data Replication
glossary.definition: A strategy used to mitigate the potential of data loss in the event of a system or component failure. In the most basic form, it involves writing identical data to more than one device or location. More efficient techniques like erasure coding incorporate mathematics to recover lost data without referring to an explicit copy of the data.

glossary.name: Database
glossary.definition: A tool used to collect and organize data. Typically, database management systems allow users to interact with the database.

glossary.name: Decision Point
glossary.definition: Also decision rule or threshold, is a cut-off point in which anything below the cutoff is determined to be a certain class and anything above the cut-off is the other class.

glossary.name: Decision Tree
glossary.definition: A tree-based model which traverses examples down to leaf nodes by the properties of the examples features.

glossary.name: Deep Learning
glossary.definition: Optimizing neural networks, often with many hidden layers, to perform unsupervised or supervised learning.

glossary.name: Dependent Variable
glossary.definition: A variable whose variation depends on other variables.

glossary.name: Derivative
glossary.definition: Indicates how much the output of a function will change with respect to a change in its input.

glossary.name: Dimensionality Reduction
glossary.definition: The process of reducing the dimensionality of features. This is typically useful to speed up the training of models and in some cases, allow for a wider number of machine learning algorithms to be used on the examples. This can be done with SVD (or PCA) and as well, certain types of neural networks such as autoencoders.

glossary.name: Dimensions
glossary.definition: Here, the number of features associated with a particular example.

glossary.name: Discriminative Model
glossary.definition: A model which aims to approximate the conditional probability of the features and labels.

glossary.name: Distributed Cache
glossary.definition: A cache which is distributed across two or more machines

glossary.name: Dot product
glossary.definition: Here, the inner product, such that two provided vectors are element-wise multiplied followed by summing each result to produce a scalar.

glossary.name: Downsampling
glossary.definition: Removing a number of majority class examples. Typically done in addition to upweighting.

glossary.name: Dropout
glossary.definition: A regularization technique used per layer to reduce overfitting. Dropout involves randomly omitting neurons from the neural network structure at each training iteration. Effectively, dropout produces an ensemble of neural networks. Dropout is incomplete without adjusting for the dropout in preparation for prediction

glossary.name: Early Stopping
glossary.definition: Halting the gradient descent process prior to approaching a minima or maxima.

glossary.name: Echo Chamber
glossary.definition: A state of a recommendation system in which user behavior is reinforced by the recommendations themselves.

glossary.name: Eigendecomposition
glossary.definition: Applicable only to square matrices, the method of factoring a matrix into its eigenvalues and eigenvectors. An eigenvector is a vector which applies a linear transformation to some matrix being factored. The eigenvalues scale the eigenvector values.

glossary.name: Elastic MapReduce (EMR)
glossary.definition: An Amazon Web Services product which provides users access to a Hadoop cluster.

glossary.name: Elbow Method
glossary.definition: A method of finding the best value for k in k-means. It involves finding the elbow of the plot of a range of ks and their respective inertias.

glossary.name: Embedding Layer
glossary.definition: Typically used as the first layer in a neural network which is optimized to transform the input in an effort to maximize.

glossary.name: Embedding Space
glossary.definition: The n-dimensional space where embeddings exist. Typically, the embedding space can be used to generate the top-k candidates by using the k-nearest neighbors algorithm.

glossary.name: Ensemble
glossary.definition: Using more than one model to produce a single prediction.

glossary.name: Epoch
glossary.definition: One complete cycle of training on all of the examples.

glossary.name: Euclidean Distance
glossary.definition: The length of the line between two points.

glossary.name: Evidence
glossary.definition: The denominator of the Naive Bayes classifier.

glossary.name: Exactly-once Semantics
glossary.definition: Guarantees that an object within a distributed system is processed exactly once. Other semantics include maybe, at-least-once, and at-most-once

glossary.name: Examples
glossary.definition: Pairs of features and labels.

glossary.name: Experiment Collision
glossary.definition: The event where one experiment unintentionally influences the result of one or more separate experiments.

glossary.name: Exploding Gradient
glossary.definition: The repeated multiplication of large gradients resulting in an overflow, or infinity-value products.

glossary.name: F1 Score
glossary.definition: The harmonic mean of the precision and recall.

glossary.name: Feature Hashing
glossary.definition: Representing feature inputs, such as articles or messages, as the result of hashes modded by predetermined value.

glossary.name: Feature Interaction
glossary.definition: Features that are multiplied by one another in order to express relationships that can't be represented by adding the independent variable terms together.

glossary.name: Feature Map
glossary.definition: The result of applying a kernel to an image or to another feature map.

glossary.name: Feature Normalization
glossary.definition: Typically referring to feature scaling that places the values of a feature between 0 and 1.

glossary.name: Feature Standardization
glossary.definition: Typically referring to feature scaling that centers the values of a feature around the mean of the feature and scales by the standard deviation of the feature.

glossary.name: Feature Transformation
glossary.definition: A mathematical function applied to features.

glossary.name: Features
glossary.definition: A set of quantities or properties describing an observation. They can be binary like "day" and "night"; categorical like "morning", "afternoon", and "evening"; continuous like 3.141; or ordinal like "threatened", "endangered", "extinct", where the categories can be ordered.

glossary.name: Featurization
glossary.definition: The process of transforming raw inputs into something a model can perform training and predictions on.

glossary.name: Flatten Layer
glossary.definition: Takes in a series of stacked feature maps and flattens out all of the values into a single feature vector.

glossary.name: Forward Pass
glossary.definition: Calculating an output of a neural network for a particular input.

glossary.name: Fully Connected Neural Network
glossary.definition: A neural network that has every neuron connected to every other neuron in the subsequent layer; also called a dense layer.

glossary.name: Gated Recurrent Unit
glossary.definition: A type of RNN with a hidden state, update gate, and reset gate.

glossary.name: Gaussian Distribution
glossary.definition: A very common type of probability distribution which fits many real world observations; also called a normal distribution.

glossary.name: Generalize
glossary.definition: The ability of a model to perform well on the test set as well as examples beyond the test set.

glossary.name: Generative Adversarial Networks
glossary.definition: Also GANs, take advantage of a concept called adversarial min max. The generator generates fake data and tries to minimize a particular loss function and the discriminator tries to correctly identify fake data from real data in an effort to maximize a particular loss function.

glossary.name: Generative Model
glossary.definition: A model which aims to approximate the joint probability of the features and labels.

glossary.name: Gini Impurity
glossary.definition: Used as a way to determine the best split point for a given node in a classification tree. It's based on the probability of incorrectly classifying an item based on all of the items in the node.

glossary.name: Gower Distance
glossary.definition: Used to calculate the distance between two points which have mixed feature types.

glossary.name: Gradient
glossary.definition: A vector of partial derivatives. In terms of neural networks, we often use the analytical gradient in software and use the numerical gradient as a gradient checking mechanism to ensure the analytical gradient is accurate.

glossary.name: Gradient Clipping
glossary.definition: Capping the value that the gradient is allowed to be. This is typically used in an effort to avoid exploding gradients. However, initialization techniques are favored.

glossary.name: Gradient Descent
glossary.definition: An iterative algorithm with the goal of optimizing some parameters of a given function with respect to some loss function. If done in batches, all of the examples are considered for an iteration of gradient descent. In mini-batch gradient descent, a subset of examples are considered for a single iteration. Stochastic gradient descent considers a single example per gradient descent iteration.

glossary.name: Graphics Processing Unit
glossary.definition:
A specialized device that has many cores, allowing it to perform many operations at a time.

GPUs are often used within deep learning to accelerate training of neural networks by taking advantage of their ability to perform many parallel computations.

glossary.name: Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS)
glossary.definition: An open-source Apache software product which provides a distributed storage framework.

glossary.name: Hamming Distance
glossary.definition: The sum of the non-matching categorical feature values.

glossary.name: Hard Disk Drive (HDD)
glossary.definition: A storage device which operates by setting bits on a spinning magnetic disk. The capacity and the read/write performance of the HDD are the main characteristics to consider when using an HDD within a particular system.

glossary.name: Heuristic
glossary.definition: An approach to finding a solution which is typically faster but less accurate than some optimal solution.

glossary.name: Hidden layer
glossary.definition: A layer that's not the input or output layer in a neural network.

glossary.name: Hidden State
glossary.definition: The output of the Recurrent Neural Network at the previous timestep.

glossary.name: Hinge Loss
glossary.definition: A loss function which is used by a soft-margin SVM.

glossary.name: Hyperbolic Tangent
glossary.definition: A symmetric activation function which ranges from -1 to 1.

glossary.name: Hyperparameter
glossary.definition: Any parameter associated with a model which is not learned.

glossary.name: Hyperparameter Optimization
glossary.definition: The process of searching for the best possible values for the hyperparameters of some machine learning model.

glossary.name: Hyperplane
glossary.definition: A decision boundary in any dimension.

glossary.name: Image Kernel
glossary.definition: A single array consisting of some defined numbers, which is applied to an image for some desired effect. Usually used in the context of image filtering.

glossary.name: Image Padding
glossary.definition: Adding a border of zero-valued pixels to an input image. The goal of padding is typically to ensure that the dimensions of an image remain the same after applying an image kernel. Libraries typically allow two options: Valid Padding, which means not to pad the image, and Same Padding, which means to zero-pad the image.

glossary.name: Implicit Rating
glossary.definition: A rating obtained from user behavior as opposed to surveying the user.

glossary.name: Implicit Relevance Feedback
glossary.definition: Feedback obtained from user behavior as opposed to surveying the user.

glossary.name: In-memory Database
glossary.definition: A database which relies either solely or primarily on the RAM of a computer.

glossary.name: Independent Variable
glossary.definition: A variable whose variation is independent from other variables.

glossary.name: Inertia
glossary.definition: The sum of distances between each point and the centroid.

glossary.name: Initialization Techniques
glossary.definition: Ways to cleverly initialize the weights of neural networks in an attempt avoid vanishing and exploding gradients. Kaiming initialization, used with asymmetric activation functions and Xavier/Glorot initialization, used with symmetric activation functions are both examples. These techniques usually depend on the fan in and fan out per layer.

glossary.name: Inverse User Frequency
glossary.definition: The added modelling assumption that if a user interacts with a less overall popular item, then the interaction should count for more.

glossary.name: Irreducible Error
glossary.definition: The error produced from the noise within the training examples which can't be eliminated with models.

glossary.name: Jaccard Distance
glossary.definition: One minus the ratio of the number of like binary feature values and the number of like and unlike binary feature values, excluding instances of matching zeros.

glossary.name: Jupyter Notebook
glossary.definition: A Project Jupyter product which provides an interactive workspace to execute code.

glossary.name: K-means++
glossary.definition: Using a weighted probability distribution as a way to find the initial centroid locations for the k-means algorithm.

glossary.name: Keras
glossary.definition: Software that acts as an interface for Tensorflow and aims to simplify the experience of working with neural networks.

glossary.name: Kernel Density Estimation
glossary.definition: Also KDE, a way to estimate the probability distribution of some data.

glossary.name: Kernel Trick
glossary.definition: The process of finding the dot product of a high dimensional representation of feature without computing the high dimensional representation itself. A common kernel is the Radial Basis Function kernel.

glossary.name: L2 Loss
glossary.definition: The sum of the squared errors of all the training examples. Not to be confused with L2 regularization.

glossary.name: Labels
glossary.definition: Usually paired with a set of features for use in supervised learning. Can be discrete or continuous.

glossary.name: Laplace Smoothing
glossary.definition: A type of additive smoothing which mitigates the chance of encountering zero probabilities within the Naive Bayes classifier.

glossary.name: Learning Rate
glossary.definition: A multiple, typically less than 1, used during the parameter update step during model training to smooth the learning process.

glossary.name: Lemmatization
glossary.definition: A more calculated form of stemming which ensures the proper lemma results from removing the word modifiers.

glossary.name: LightGBM
glossary.definition: An open-source library created by Microsoft which provides a distributed gradient boosted framework. Short for Light Gradient Boosted Models.

glossary.name: Likelihood
glossary.definition: The probability of some features given a particular class.

glossary.name: Line of Best Fit
glossary.definition: The line through data points which best describe the relationship of a dependent variable with one or more independent variables. Ordinary least squares can be used to find the line of best fit.

glossary.name: Linear Activation
glossary.definition: A symmetric activation function which assigns the output as the value of the input.

glossary.name: Local Optima
glossary.definition: A maxima or minima which is not the global optima.

glossary.name: Long Short-term Memory
glossary.definition: A type of RNN with a cell and hidden state, input gate, forget gate, and an output gate.

glossary.name: Manhattan Distance
glossary.definition: Sum of the absolute differences of two input features.

glossary.name: Margin
glossary.definition: The space between the hyperplane and the support vectors. In the case of soft margin Support Vector Machines, this margin includes slack.

glossary.name: Matrix
glossary.definition: An array of values, usually consisting of multiple rows and columns.

glossary.name: Matrix Factorization
glossary.definition: Factors the user-item matrix into embeddings such that multiplying together the resulting embedding layers gives an estimate for the original user-item matrix.

glossary.name: Matrix Transpose
glossary.definition: An operator that flips a matrix over its diagonal.

glossary.name: Mcfadden's Pseudo R-squared
glossary.definition: An analog to linear regression's R-squared which typically takes on smaller values than the traditional R-squared.

glossary.name: Mean Absolute Error
glossary.definition: The average of the absolute differences across the training examples.

glossary.name: Mean Average Precision
glossary.definition: A binary ranking metric which takes into account the relevance of ranked items with regards to their position.

glossary.name: Mean Reciprocal Rank
glossary.definition: A binary ranking metric which takes into account the first spot in a ranking which contains a relevant item.

glossary.name: Mean Squared Error
glossary.definition: The average squared difference between the prediction and true label across all examples.

glossary.name: Mechanical Turk
glossary.definition: A crowdsourcing service which performs on-demand tasks that computers are currently unable to do.

glossary.name: Missing Data
glossary.definition: When some features within an example are missing.

glossary.name: MLlib
glossary.definition: A library provided by Apache Spark which provides Spark clusters access to machine learning algorithms and related utilities. MLlib provides a Dataframe-based API which is unofficially referred to as Spark ML.

glossary.name: Mode Collapse
glossary.definition: A challenge of training GANs in which the generator generates data which successfully confuses the discriminator and so the generator exploits this vulnerability and only produces that particular data over and over. A way to mitigate this is to force the generator to see responses from the discriminator multiple timesteps ahead. One such method is called an Unrolled GAN.

glossary.name: Model
glossary.definition: An approximation of a relationship between an input and an output.

glossary.name: Model Parallelism
glossary.definition: A machine learning model training strategy used to maximize the utilization of compute resources (CPUs/GPUs) in which the model is distributed across two or more devices.

glossary.name: Model Training
glossary.definition: Determining the model parameter values.

glossary.name: Momentum
glossary.definition: A concept applied to gradient descent in which the gradients applied to the weight updates depends on previous gradients.

glossary.name: Multi-Armed Bandit (MAB)
glossary.definition: A process which provides a number of choices

glossary.name: Multinomial Distribution
glossary.definition: A distribution which models the probability of counts of particular outcomes.

glossary.name: Multinomial Logistic Regression
glossary.definition: Logistic Regression in which there are more than two classes to be predicted across.

glossary.name: N-gram
glossary.definition: A series of adjacent words of length n.

glossary.name: Neuron
glossary.definition: Sometimes called a perceptron, a neuron is a graphical representation of the smallest part of a neural network. For the Machine Learning Crash Course we may reference neurons as nodes or units.

glossary.name: Non-convex Function
glossary.definition: A function which has two or more instances of zero-slope.

glossary.name: Non-differentiable
glossary.definition: A function which has kinks in which a derivative is not defined.

glossary.name: Nonlinear Regression
glossary.definition: A type of regression which models nonlinear relationships in the independent variables.

glossary.name: Norm
glossary.definition: Here, the L2 Norm, is the square root of the sum of squares of each element in a vector.

glossary.name: Normalized Discounted Cumulative Gain
glossary.definition: An information retrieval metric which assigns a value of a particular ranking based on each item's position and relevance.

glossary.name: Numba
glossary.definition: A just-in-time Python compiler which resolves a subset of the python programming language down to machine code

glossary.name: Odds Ratio
glossary.definition: The degree of associate between two events. If the odds ratio is 1, then the two events are independent. If the odds ratio is greater than 1, the events are positively correlated, otherwise the events are negatively correlated.

glossary.name: OLAP
glossary.definition: Online analytical processing. A system that handles the analytical processes of a business, including reporting, auditing, and business intelligence. For example, this may be a Hadoop cluster which maintains user subscription history for Netflix. This is opposed to OLTP.

glossary.name: OLTP
glossary.definition: Online transaction processing. A system that handles (near) real-time business processes. For example, a database that maintains a table of the users subscribed to Netflix and which is then used to enable successful log-ins would be considered OLTP. This is opposed to OLAP.

glossary.name: One-hot Encoding
glossary.definition: An encoding for categorical variables where every value that a variable can take on is represented as a binary vector

glossary.name: Online Learning
glossary.definition: Incremental learning within a model to represent an incrementally changing population.

glossary.name: Optimizers
glossary.definition: Techniques which attempt to optimize gradient descent

glossary.name: Orthogonal
glossary.definition: Perpendicular is n-dimensions.

glossary.name: Outlier
glossary.definition: A feature or group of features which vary significantly from the other features.

glossary.name: P-value
glossary.definition: The probability of finding a particular result, or a greater result, given a null hypothesis being true.

glossary.name: Parallelization
glossary.definition: When two or more computer programs are executed at the same instant across more than one processor.

glossary.name: Parameter
glossary.definition: Any trained value in a model.

glossary.name: Parameters
glossary.definition: Also, weights, or coefficients. Values to be learned during the model training.

glossary.name: Parquet
glossary.definition: A column-oriented data storage format provided by Apache.

glossary.name: Partial Derivative
glossary.definition: The derivative of a function with respect to a single variable.

glossary.name: Pearson Correlation
glossary.definition: A measure of the correlation between two inputs. In the context of recommendation systems. Pearson correlation can be used to construct an item-item similarity matrix.

glossary.name: Polynomial
glossary.definition: A function with more than one variable/coefficient pair.

glossary.name: Pooling
glossary.definition: Most often max pooling and sometimes average pooling, in which a kernel is applied to an image and the max or average of the pixel values in the kernel overlay is the resulting pixel value in the output image.

glossary.name: Posterior
glossary.definition: The probability of a class given some features.

glossary.name: Pre-trained Models
glossary.definition: Models which have already been trained. These trained models can be used as layers (like embedding layers) of not-yet-trained neural networks to increase performance of these neural network.

glossary.name: Precision
glossary.definition: The number of true positives divided by the true positives plus false positives.

glossary.name: Presentation and Trust Bias
glossary.definition: Biases found within ranking which arise from the placement of items within a ranking.

glossary.name: Principal Component Analysis
glossary.definition: Also PCA, is eigendecomposition performed on the covariance matrix of some particular data. The eigenvectors then describe the principle components and the eigenvalues indicate the variance described by each principal component. Typically, SVD is used to perform PCA. PCA assumes linear correlations in the data. If that assumption is not true, then you can use kernel PCA.

glossary.name: Prior
glossary.definition: Indicates the probability of a particular class regardless of the features of some example.

glossary.name: Probability
glossary.definition: How likely something is to occur. This can be independent, such as the roll of the dice, or conditional, such as drawing two cards subsequently out of a deck without replacement.

glossary.name: Probability Distribution
glossary.definition: A function that takes in an outcome and outputs the probability of that particular outcome occurring.

glossary.name: Pruning Neurons
glossary.definition: Removing neurons from a neural network in an effort to reduce the number of model parameters if by removing the neurons, equivalent performance can be obtained.

glossary.name: R-squared
glossary.definition: Also the coefficient of determination, the percent of variance in the dependent variable explained by the independent variable(s).

glossary.name: Random Access Memory (RAM)
glossary.definition: A device on a computer which stores the data and machine code of a running computer program.

glossary.name: Random Forest
glossary.definition: An ensemble technique which trains many independent weak learners. This generally reduces the variance error.

glossary.name: Rank r Approximation
glossary.definition: Using up to, and including, the rth terms in the singular value decomposition to approximate an original matrix.

glossary.name: Ranking
glossary.definition: Optimizing machine learning models to rank candidates, such as music, articles, or products. Typically, the goal is to order the candidates such that the candidates which are most likely to be interacted with (purchased, viewed, liked, etc.) are above other candidates that aren't as likely to be interacted with.

glossary.name: Recall
glossary.definition: Also sensitivity, is the proportion of true positives which are correctly classified.

glossary.name: Receiver Operator Characteristic Curve
glossary.definition: Also ROC curve, is a plot of how the specificity and sensitivity change as the decision threshold changes. The area under the ROC curve, or AUC, is the probability that a randomly chosen positive example will have a higher prediction probability of being positive than a randomly chosen negative example.

glossary.name: Receptive Field
glossary.definition: The number of neurons in a preceding layer which are connected to an adjacent layer of neurons. The largest receptive field is a fully-connected neural network.

glossary.name: Recommendation Carousel
glossary.definition: A component within a graphical or conversational user interface which presents recommendations to a user. This can include products, ads, and media content.

glossary.name: Recommendation Systems
glossary.definition: Systems with the goal of presenting an item to a user such that the user will most likely purchase, view, or like the recommended item. Items can take many forms, such as music, movies, or products. Also called recommender systems.

glossary.name: Rectified Linear Unit
glossary.definition: An asymmetric activation function which outputs the value of the positive inputs and zero otherwise. There are variations such as the Leaky ReLU. They can be susceptible to the dead neuron problem but generally perform well in practice.

glossary.name: Recurrent Neural Network
glossary.definition: Also RNN, a neural network in which the output is routed back into the network to be used with the subsequent input.

glossary.name: Regularization
glossary.definition: A technique of limiting the ability for a model to overfit by encouraging the values parameters to take on smaller values.

glossary.name: Residuals
glossary.definition: The distance between points and a particular line.

glossary.name: Sample Selection Bias
glossary.definition: The bias that occurs when sampling a population into one or more subgroups at random results in a systematic inclusion or exclusion of some data.

glossary.name: Sample Size
glossary.definition: The number of observations taken from a complete population.

glossary.name: Scalar
glossary.definition: A single value, as opposed to a vector.

glossary.name: scikit-learn
glossary.definition: A machine learning python library which provides implementations of regression, classification, and clustering.

glossary.name: Seasonality
glossary.definition: The predictable changes of data throughout the calendar year.

glossary.name: Sensitivity
glossary.definition: Also recall, is the proportion of true positives which are correctly classified.

glossary.name: Session ID
glossary.definition: A unique identifier assigned to a user to keep track of a user's connected interactions. For instance, a session may include a user logging in, purchasing an item, and logging out. Here, the session ID would be used to reference the group of those three interactions. This session ID can be stored in the user's internet browser as a cookie.

glossary.name: Shadow Test
glossary.definition: Running two or more versions of software in parallel while only surfacing the result of one of the experiences to the end user. This is done in an effort to gauge the differences between the software versions.

glossary.name: Shift Invariance
glossary.definition: One of the goals of a convolutional neural network: objects within an image can be in different areas of the image yet still be recognized.

glossary.name: Shilling Attack
glossary.definition: A type of attack on a recommendation system in which users manipulate the recommendations by inflating or deflating positive interactions for their own or competing items.

glossary.name: Shrinkage
glossary.definition: A learning rate for gradient boosted trees.

glossary.name: Side Features
glossary.definition: Features in addition to item and user embeddings. This can include properties of items and users.

glossary.name: Sigmoid Function
glossary.definition: Also the logistic function, a function which outputs a range from 0 to 1.

glossary.name: Silhouette Method
glossary.definition: A method of finding the best value for k in k-means. It takes into account the ratios of the inter and intra clusters distances.

glossary.name: Simple Matching Distance
glossary.definition: One minus the ratio of the number of like binary feature values and the number of like and unlike binary feature values.

glossary.name: Simpson's Paradox
glossary.definition: When a pattern emerges in segments of examples but is no longer present when the segments are grouped together.

glossary.name: Singular Value Decomposition
glossary.definition: Also SVD, a process which decomposes a matrix into rotation and scaling terms. It is a generalization of eigendecomposition.

glossary.name: Slack
glossary.definition: The relaxing of the constraint that all examples must lie outside of the margin. This creates a soft-margin SVM.

glossary.name: Softmax
glossary.definition: A sigmoid which is generalized to more than two classes to be predicted against.

glossary.name: SparkML
glossary.definition: Refers to APIs which provide machine learning capabilities on Spark dataframes.

glossary.name: Specificity
glossary.definition: The proportion of true negatives which are correctly classified.

glossary.name: Split Point
glossary.definition: A pair of feature and feature value which is assigned to a node in a decision tree. This split point will determine which examples will go left and which examples go right based on the feature and feature value.

glossary.name: Standard Deviation
glossary.definition: The amount of deviation around the mean for a particular distribution

glossary.name: statsmodels
glossary.definition: Python module which provides various statistical tools.

glossary.name: Stemming
glossary.definition: Removing the ending modifiers of words, leaving the stem of the word.

glossary.name: Stop Word
glossary.definition: A word, typically discarded, which doesn't add much predictive value.

glossary.name: Stride
glossary.definition: The incremental rate at which a kernel is applied to an image or feature map.

glossary.name: Sub-gradient
glossary.definition: The gradient of a non-differentiable function.

glossary.name: Supervised Learning
glossary.definition: Optimizing machine learning models based on previously observed features and labels. Typically, the goal is to attach the most likely label to some provided features.

glossary.name: Support Vectors
glossary.definition: The most difficult to separate points in regard to a decision boundary. They influence the location and orientation of the hyperplane.

glossary.name: Surrogate Split
glossary.definition: A suboptimal split point reserved for examples which are missing the optimal split point feature.

glossary.name: TF-IDF
glossary.definition: Short for Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency, TF-IDF is a method of transforming features, usually representing counts of words, into values representing the overall importance of different words across some documents.

glossary.name: Time Decay
glossary.definition: The added modelling assumption that interactions between items and users should count for less over time.

glossary.name: Tokenization
glossary.definition: The splitting of some raw textual input into individual words or elements.

glossary.name: Unbalanced Classes
glossary.definition: When one class is far more frequently observed than another class.

glossary.name: Uniform Distribution
glossary.definition: A probability distribution in which each outcome is equally likely; for example, rolling a normal six-sided die.

glossary.name: Unsupervised Learning
glossary.definition: An approach within machine learning that takes in unlabeled examples and produces patterns from the provided data. Typically, the goal is to discover something previously unknown about the unlabeled examples.

glossary.name: Upweighting
glossary.definition: Increasing the impact a minority class example has on the loss function. Typically done in addition to downsampling.

glossary.name: User Agent
glossary.definition: An identifier used to describe the software application which a user is using to interact with another software application. For instance, an HTTP request to a website typically includes the user agent so that the website knows how to render the webpage.

glossary.name: User-item Matrix
glossary.definition: A matrix which contains the interactions of users and items. Items can take the form of products, music, and videos.

glossary.name: Validation
glossary.definition: The technique of holding out some portion of examples to be tested separately from the set of examples used to train the model.

glossary.name: Vanishing Gradient
glossary.definition: The repeated multiplication of small gradients resulting in an underflow, or 0-value products.

glossary.name: Variance
glossary.definition: The standard deviation squared.

glossary.name: Variance Inflation Factor
glossary.definition: A measure of multicollinearity in a regression model.

glossary.name: Vector
glossary.definition: Here, a feature vector, which is a list of features representing a particular example.

glossary.name: Vectorizer
glossary.definition: Used in a step of featurizing. It transforms some input into something else. One example is a binary vectorizer which transforms tokenized messages into a binary vector indicating which items in the vocabulary appear in the message.

glossary.name: Vocabulary
glossary.definition: The list of words that the Naive Bayes classifier recognizes.

glossary.name: Weak Learner
glossary.definition: Shallow decision trees in our case. However, it generally can be any underfitting model.

glossary.name: XGBoost
glossary.definition: An open-source library which provides a gradient boosted framework. Short for Extreme Gradient Boosting.

glossary.name: Zookeeper
glossary.definition: A service designed to reliably coordinate distributed systems via naming service, configuration management, data synchronization, leader election, message queuing, or notification systems.

fundamentals.name: Introduction
fundamentals.description:
Welcome to our series on Large-Scale Machine Learning! Here, we'll really dig into some of the more practical applications of the field and equip you with the tools you need to design and build complex machine-learning systems for enterprise-level businesses.

Are you ready to take your knowledge and expertise to the next level?

fundamentals.name: Data Ingestion
fundamentals.description:
In order to do anything with a machine-learning system, you first need to feed it some inputs. In this first video of the series, we'll look at technologies you can use to ingest data into your systems and review some considerations you can make throughout this process.

Let's dive in!

keyTerms.name: Clickstream
keyTerms.definition: An ordered series of interactions that users have with some interface. In the traditional sense, this can be literal clicks of a mouse on a desktop browser. Interactions can also come from touchscreens and conversational user interfaces.

keyTerms.name: Change Data Capture
keyTerms.definition:
The process of recording changes in the data within a database system. For instance, if a user cancels their Netflix subscription, then the row in some table will change to indicate that they're no longer a subscriber.

The change in this row can be recorded and referenced later for analysis or audit purposes.

keyTerms.name: Apache Kafka
keyTerms.definition: An open-source software platform which provides a way to handle real-time data streaming.

keyTerms.name: Amazon Kinesis
keyTerms.definition: An AWS product that provides a way to handle real-time data streaming.

keyTerms.name: Zookeeper
keyTerms.definition: A service designed to reliably coordinate distributed systems via naming service, configuration management, data synchronization, leader election, message queuing, or notification systems.

keyTerms.name: Database
keyTerms.definition: A tool used to collect and organize data. Typically, database management systems allow users to interact with the database.

keyTerms.name: OLTP
keyTerms.definition: Online transaction processing. A system that handles (near) real-time business processes. For example, a database that maintains a table of the users subscribed to Netflix and which is then used to enable successful log-ins would be considered OLTP. This is opposed to OLAP.

keyTerms.name: OLAP
keyTerms.definition: Online analytical processing. A system that handles the analytical processes of a business, including reporting, auditing, and business intelligence. For example, this may be a Hadoop cluster which maintains user subscription history for Netflix. This is opposed to OLTP.

keyTerms.name: Availability Zone (AZ)
keyTerms.definition: Typically a single data center within a region which has two or more data centers. The term "multi-AZ" implies that an application or software resource is present across more than one AZ within a region. This strategy allows the software resource to continue operating even if a data center becomes unavailable.

fundamentals.name: Data Storage
fundamentals.description:
If you've gone through our Systems Design Fundamental series, then you know how important having a high-performing storage model is to any system.

And guess what? Massive, computationally-intense ML systems are certainly no exception!

keyTerms.name: Hard Disk Drive (HDD)
keyTerms.definition: A storage device which operates by setting bits on a spinning magnetic disk. The capacity and the read/write performance of the HDD are the main characteristics to consider when using an HDD within a particular system.

keyTerms.name: Data Replication
keyTerms.definition: A strategy used to mitigate the potential of data loss in the event of a system or component failure. In the most basic form, it involves writing identical data to more than one device or location. More efficient techniques like erasure coding incorporate mathematics to recover lost data without referring to an explicit copy of the data.

keyTerms.name: Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS)
keyTerms.definition: An open-source Apache software product which provides a distributed storage framework.

keyTerms.name: Avro
keyTerms.definition: A row-oriented data serializer provided by Apache.

keyTerms.name: Parquet
keyTerms.definition: A column-oriented data storage format provided by Apache.

keyTerms.name: Exactly-once Semantics
keyTerms.definition: Guarantees that an object within a distributed system is processed exactly once. Other semantics include maybe, at-least-once, and at-most-once

fundamentals.name: Data Processing
fundamentals.description:
Ingesting and storing data into your system is great, but without a robust processing engine in place to extract features and labels from that data, you won't get very far.

Fortunately, as is often the case in the software engineering world, Apache comes in clutch with some nifty solutions to our woes.

keyTerms.name: Recommendation Carousel
keyTerms.definition: A component within a graphical or conversational user interface which presents recommendations to a user. This can include products, ads, and media content.

keyTerms.name: Central Processing Unit (CPU)
keyTerms.definition: A general purpose compute resource responsible for executing computer programs.

keyTerms.name: Seasonality
keyTerms.definition: The predictable changes of data throughout the calendar year.

keyTerms.name: Parallelization
keyTerms.definition: When two or more computer programs are executed at the same instant across more than one processor.

keyTerms.name: Random Access Memory (RAM)
keyTerms.definition: A device on a computer which stores the data and machine code of a running computer program.

keyTerms.name: Apache Spark
keyTerms.definition: A software interface which provides implicit parallelism and fault tolerance across a cluster of machines.

keyTerms.name: Apache YARN
keyTerms.definition: A software product responsible for managing compute resources across a cluster of machines.

keyTerms.name: Elastic MapReduce (EMR)
keyTerms.definition: An Amazon Web Services product which provides users access to a Hadoop cluster.

keyTerms.name: Jupyter Notebook
keyTerms.definition: A Project Jupyter product which provides an interactive workspace to execute code.

fundamentals.name: Processing Orchestration
fundamentals.description:
In the previous video, we looked at how you might go about manually processing data. This obviously isn't scalable, so the next step is to remove the human element and fully automate the process.

Luckily, and perhaps unsurprisingly, we can once again turn to Apache to help us accomplish this goal!

keyTerms.name: Apache Airflow
keyTerms.definition: A workflow management system that provides users a way to author, schedule, and execute software.

fundamentals.name: Workspaces
fundamentals.description: With your data-support pipeline in place, the final missing piece of the puzzle is setting up an organized workspace from which you can explore all of your model combinations and ultimately manage every single bitâ€”pun absolutely intendedâ€”of data.

keyTerms.name: Automated Machine Learning (Auto-ML)
keyTerms.definition: A strategy which automates the process of applying features and labels to a machine learning model.

keyTerms.name: Data Governance
keyTerms.definition: The method of managing, using, and protecting an organization's data.

fundamentals.name: Frequentist AB Testing
fundamentals.description: A: Here, we'll introduce A/B testingâ€”from the frequently used frequentist perspective. B: Here, we'll cover frequentist A/B testingâ€”don't tell the Bayesians!

keyTerms.name: A/B Testing
keyTerms.definition: The process of providing two or more different experiences across two or more subgroups of a population. The goal is to measure the change in behavior of the subgroups upon receiving the respective experiences.

keyTerms.name: A/A Test
keyTerms.definition: An A/B test in which the experiences being tested are identical to one another. This is done in an effort to determine statistical validity of the A/B tool, the metric being monitored, and the analysis process being used.

keyTerms.name: User Agent
keyTerms.definition: An identifier used to describe the software application which a user is using to interact with another software application. For instance, an HTTP request to a website typically includes the user agent so that the website knows how to render the webpage.

keyTerms.name: Session ID
keyTerms.definition: A unique identifier assigned to a user to keep track of a user's connected interactions. For instance, a session may include a user logging in, purchasing an item, and logging out. Here, the session ID would be used to reference the group of those three interactions. This session ID can be stored in the user's internet browser as a cookie.

keyTerms.name: Cookie
keyTerms.definition: A small piece of data stored by a browser which indicates stateful information for a particular website. For instance, a cookie can be stored in your browser after you log in to a website to indicate that you are logged in. This will stop subsequent pages from asking you to log in again.

fundamentals.name: Bayesian AB Testing
fundamentals.description:
Using your prior knowledge, there's a strong likelihood that you'll see the benefits of using Bayesian A/B tests over frequentist A/B tests. 

If not, you can always A/B test them.

keyTerms.name: Beta Distribution
keyTerms.definition: This distribution is used to model percentages and proportions such as click-through probabilities.

fundamentals.name: Multi-Armed Bandit
fundamentals.description: While the multi-armed bandit we'll be covering here isn't a kraken plundering gold from pirate ships (that would be pretty cool), the idea of a monstrous cephalopod pillaging vessels is a surprisingly decent metaphor for this alternative to A/B testing!

keyTerms.name: Multi-Armed Bandit (MAB)
keyTerms.definition: A process which provides a number of choices

fundamentals.name: Impact Estimation
fundamentals.description:
In business, money talks. So if you want your super-duper cool ML projects to be given the greenlight in a business setting, you need to prove that they will yield some financial value to the company.

This video is full of tips to ensure you emerge from this series not only as an MLExpert, but also as a ProfitExpert!

keyTerms.name: Shadow Test
keyTerms.definition: Running two or more versions of software in parallel while only surfacing the result of one of the experiences to the end user. This is done in an effort to gauge the differences between the software versions.

keyTerms.name: Sample Selection Bias
keyTerms.definition: The bias that occurs when sampling a population into one or more subgroups at random results in a systematic inclusion or exclusion of some data.

keyTerms.name: Experiment Collision
keyTerms.definition: The event where one experiment unintentionally influences the result of one or more separate experiments.

fundamentals.name: Basic Models
fundamentals.description:
In the Machine Learning Crash Course, we looked at a number of basic machine-learning models you can use, but we did so from a simplified, theoretical point of view.

It's time to revisit some of these models and explore how we can alter them to work in a large, enterprise-level data setting.

keyTerms.name: MLlib
keyTerms.definition: A library provided by Apache Spark which provides Spark clusters access to machine learning algorithms and related utilities. MLlib provides a Dataframe-based API which is unofficially referred to as Spark ML.

fundamentals.name: Deep Learning Models
fundamentals.description:
Just like in the previous video, we're going to put the practical in the academic and take a deeperâ€”pun, as usual, intendedâ€”look at deep-learning models.

Fire up that play button!

keyTerms.name: Model Parallelism
keyTerms.definition: A machine learning model training strategy used to maximize the utilization of compute resources (CPUs/GPUs) in which the model is distributed across two or more devices.

keyTerms.name: Data Parallelism
keyTerms.definition: A machine learning model training strategy used to maximize the utilization of compute resources (CPUs/GPUs) in which the data is distributed across two or more devices

keyTerms.name: Graphics Processing Unit
keyTerms.definition:
A specialized device that has many cores, allowing it to perform many operations at a time.

GPUs are often used within deep learning to accelerate training of neural networks by taking advantage of their ability to perform many parallel computations.

keyTerms.name: Concurrency
keyTerms.definition: When two or computer programs share a single processor.

fundamentals.name: Model Validation
fundamentals.description:
The hyperparameter tuning process of complex, business-grade ML models can often cost hundreds of thousands of dollars, so it is imperative to optimize this process in a way that minimizes its cost.

Remember, you cannot be a true MLExpert without also being a seasoned ProfitExpert!

keyTerms.name: Hyperparameter Optimization
keyTerms.definition: The process of searching for the best possible values for the hyperparameters of some machine learning model.

fundamentals.name: Productionization
fundamentals.description: Transitioning your model from the experimentation phase to a live production environment is the final step! A lot of time, money, and resources have been invested at this point, so it's critical to reduce the human-error element as much as possible to ensure a smooth and successful launch.

preReqs.name: Recall
preReqs.definition: Also sensitivity, is the proportion of true positives which are correctly classified.

preReqs.name: Precision
preReqs.definition: The number of true positives divided by the true positives plus false positives.

fundamentals.name: Data Hosting
fundamentals.description:
Production environments have stricter performance requirements than testing environments, especially with regards to latency; after all, you're serving real users, so every millisecond is precious!

In this video, we'll look at how we can leverage in-memory databases and distributed caching to crush latency and keep users happy.

keyTerms.name: In-memory Database
keyTerms.definition: A database which relies either solely or primarily on the RAM of a computer.

keyTerms.name: Distributed Cache
keyTerms.definition: A cache which is distributed across two or more machines

fundamentals.name: Model Hosting
fundamentals.description:
You've made it to the finish line! In this final video of the Large-Scale Machine-Learning series, we'll continue down the hosting-optimization rabbit hole we previously dove into.

A true MLExpert isn't satisfied until they've eradicated all traces of latency from their systems, even when serving millions of users!

keyTerms.name: Numba
keyTerms.definition: A just-in-time Python compiler which resolves a subset of the python programming language down to machine code
